Assumption: Storm drainage network includes approximately 800-1200 LM (linear meters) of pipe ranging from DN150 to DN600, serving tank farm, railcar unloading area, and marine loading platform access areas.
Storm drainage system includes approximately 15-25 manholes and 25-40 catch basins based on typical industrial facility layout.

OWS system includes 1 packaged oil-water separator unit with treatment capacity 50-100 L/s, separator volume 10-20 m³, instrumentation (level sensors, flow meters, oil layer monitors, alarms), and associated piping/sumps.
Duct bank network includes approximately 400-600 LM of duct bank with 4-8 conduits per bank, concrete encasement, 10-15 pull boxes, serving electrical and communications infrastructure from PKG-17.

Trenchless crossings include approximately 4-8 crossings beneath existing rail tracks, roads, or utilities, using auger boring or horizontal directional drilling (HDD), with casing pipe sizes DN200 to DN600, crossing lengths 15-40 m each.
Engineering effort for PKG-03 includes approximately 1,200-1,600 hours total for all 6 deliverables, distributed across:
Construction labor productivity is standard for BC Lower Mainland (productivity factor = 1.0); no site-specific constraints that would reduce productivity.

Site soil conditions are typical for Fraser River delta (soft silty soils, high groundwater, potential contamination from existing industrial operations); excavation support (shoring, dewatering) may be required for trenches deeper than 2-3m.

CCTV survey (DEL-03.06) includes inspection of all newly installed storm drainage pipes (estimated 800-1200 LM) with video recording, defect coding, reporting; cost approximately $15-25/LM plus mobilization and reporting.
Testing and commissioning (DEL-03.05) includes:

Total excavation volume for trenches (storm drainage, duct banks, utility connections) is approximately 1,500-2,500 m³; backfill volume approximately 1,200-2,000 m³ (remainder is pipe/bedding displacement).

Dewatering is required for excavations below groundwater table (estimated at 2-3m depth in Fraser River delta location); dewatering includes sump pumps, wellpoints, or deep wells depending on trench depth and groundwater conditions.
Trench shoring (trench boxes, slide rail systems, or sloped excavations) is required for trenches deeper than 1.5m per WorkSafeBC regulations; approximately 30-50% of trench length requires shoring.

Traffic management is required for utility installation in active terminal areas (truck routes, rail crossings, marine access); working hours may be restricted to minimize disruption to terminal operations (OBJ-5 Terminal Continuity).

Environmental protection measures during construction include erosion and sediment control (silt fencing, sediment ponds, inlet protection), spill prevention and response (spill kits, containment, emergency response plan), and stormwater pollution prevention (SWPPP).

Construction in Fraser Surrey area is subject to wet season (October - March) impacts on excavation and backfill operations; productivity may be reduced 10-15% during wet weather; dewatering requirements may increase.

12 fender units required for Phase 1 berth.
8 bollard units required (4 bow + 4 stern for typical Panamax mooring configuration).
